bestBHT.bht: I pray you to take some meat, for this is for your health, for there shall not a hair fall from . . . any of you, illustrates a beautiful union of confidence in the divine pledge and care for the whole ship's health and safety. It emphasizes the importance of physical safety, not just spiritual salvation. The phrase there shall not a hair fall from the head of any of you reassures that they would be preserved safe and none of them would be lost.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: I pray you to take some meat, for this is for your health, for there shall not a hair fall from . . . any of you."
On this beautiful union of confidence in the divine pledge and care for the whole ship's health and safety.
Albert Barnes: Not a hair fall from the head...that they would be preserved safe; that none of them would be lost.
None of them would be lost.
In their persons they should not experience the least damage.
Philip Schaff: This is essential for your safety.
There shall not a hair fall from the head of any of you.
It was necessary that they should recruit their strength.
Archibald T. Robertson: For this is for your safety."
Note σωτηρια in sense of 'safety,' literal meaning, not spiritual salvation.
Perish. Future middle (intransitive) of απολλυμ (-υω), to destroy.
John Gill: To sit down composedly and eat meat cheerfully and freely.
It was for the health of them all, that they might be better able to bear the shock and fatigue of the shipwreck.
There shall not a hair fall from the head of any of you, expressing the utmost safety of their lives.
John Wesley: This is for your preservation — That ye may be the better able to swim to shore.

Take some meat for your health, for there shall not a hair fall from any of you. This highlights the union of confidence in divine care and concern for the ship's safety.
